remixed_from.author: Ahasuerus
remixed_from.title: Circular fan duct for Prusa Mendel

title: Circular fan duct for Open X Carriage

description.text: This is the circular fan duct, with extra mounting holes to mount to the side of the Open X Carriage, for those few of us who haven't moved to a Prusa.  The top of the funnel is also lowered so as to make room for the belt catch tab.

Print, and bolt to the side of your carriage.  I replaced the M4 screws holding the bearing arm to the side with longer 30mm screws.  I screwed them in from the inside of the carriage and then mounted the top holes in the fan duct to them.  The duct is the perfect length to reach a makergear hot end.

comments.text: Is the airflow really reaching the opposite side? and are you using it regularly?
comments.author: Sungod3k

comments.text: Thanks for this!  Right now I just have a fan hotglued between the rails onto the OpenX carriage because I've been too lazy to do exactly what you have done here.  Thanks again.

author: tommal

title: Taranis FPV Eachine LCD 5800D Screen Mount v2.0
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
UPDATED VERSION!

In the first version the fit on Taranis and the antenna hole was with original measurments from the thing I've remixed, but they didn't fit well on my Taranis plus and with my module, so I've corrected this and call it now v2.

My Eachine LCD 5800D has an internal battery compartment, so it was to deep for the original measurements and I streched the thing by the mounting hole about 10.5mm to fit.
It's one version solid with my measurements and one .obj file, so you can ungroup with a program of your choice and change measurements of the middle part for your needs.

Printing it in ABS with supports and the orientation it drops into your slicer should be best.

comments.text:
Hi,
I've printed your screen mount, and it's very good, but have you considered moving the webbing in the taranis antenna hole to the opposite side, this way the mount would wedge between the taranis antenna button and the carrying handle, this would do away with the need to zip tie at the handle end. I see you've included the *.obj file, if you don't mind I may try remixing your design?
Regards Andrew
comments.author: adibbins

comments.text:
No problem, feel free to mix it the way you want!
Please mark your design as a remix of this thing, so I and others can find it too. ;)

description.text:
Small caps to put on your LED chains, perfect for christmas! Due to the single walled design they should be translucent with almost any filament/color. One cap needs around 13cm of 1,75mm filament.
5mm LEDs shout fit, and if not, just resize it a little tiny bit and print again. +/- 0.1mm
I printed them with 0.4mm nozzle with ABS.

Very fast and easy to print. You should have no problems printing 50+ of them in around 1,5 hours. Just becareful when pulling them off the build plate, they are fragile!

Layer Height: 2-3mm
Perimeters: 1 (single walled!)
Infill: 0%
Top/Bottom Thickness: 0
Raft: No

title: HTC Vive Controller Stock (AR-15 Buffer Tube)

description.text:
I was playing a nice round of H3 on my vive when I examined my M4 and saw that you could adjust its stock and I had a realization, what if you had a controller stock that you could put an AR stock on to have it be comfortable AND adjustable? So I came up with this design, cobbled it together in about 20 minutes and figured "Hey, that looks close enough". I know its a little rough around the edges, but I will do my best to improve it based off any feedback I get. The buffer tube itself is based off of measurements taken directly from a Palmetto State Armory mil-spec diameter tube, so any mil-spec stock you have lying around should fit it. Credit for the base design for the controller slot goes to Belllsy, I used a portion of this model to do it (Hope he doesn't mind) http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1775462

WARNING BEFORE YOU PRINT I have not had the chance to make this and see how well it works, if you make it, you make it at your own risk, but any feedback on its function would be greatly appreciated.

comments.text: I printed just the buffer tube for a buffer tube to PVC pip adapter i am working on so i can use an 3d printed AR stock on my Onward gun setup. The buffer tube was to small in diameter. I will check it against my real AR to se if it is mill spec or maybe my 3d printed at stock ins not. But it could be to small. I have modified the size an will print it again.
comments.author: SSBN506

comments.text: Thank you for the feedback, the measurements I made when making the model were taken directly off of a Palmetto State Arms buffer tube (I believe its mil-spec, but I may be wrong), though I may have messed up when actually making the model. If you make any alterations to the design that work out well, please let me know, and I'd be more than happy to give you credit where credit's due and to add the file to this page if you can get it to me so that others may use it. Again, Thank you for the feedback. -Katsar

title: Arduino CO2 Sensor v.1
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
I have printed the case in PLA with my Prusa i3 x. The MQ135 (air-quality sensor) is controlled by an Arduino Nano and connected with a HC-06 bluetooth module to interact with an Android smartphone (and see the ppm level). The magnets hold the face to the case. A yellow led will switch on when the sensor detects 1000 ppm and a red led will switch on when it detects 1500 ppm. I have decided to construct this sensor in particular for schools. Infact, I have noticed that the level of attention decreases with a high CO2 level.
I hope you can find this sensor useful!

P.s. :
-Arduino CO2 Sensor v.2: "https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2422144"
-Here the Arduino code: "http://picocurl.com/1JW1"

title: Bug Cap for Black and Decker Dust Buster

description.text:
We often use our Dust Buster to vacuum up insects inside the house. This cap keeps the bugs from getting out while you take them outside or while you hunt down their comrades.

The cap is designed for a BLACK + DECKER CHV1410L 16 volt Lithium Cordless Dust Buster Hand Vac

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

This prints with no supports if you print it upside-down and rotated to make the lid edge flat against the print bed - see the Cura screen shot.

Note about rotation in Cura: by default rotation is by 15 degrees. To rotate by 1 degree increments, hold down the shift key when you click to rotate. The model requires rotation by 140 degrees (see the Cura screen shot).

I made the angled lid especially thick so it would adhere to the print bed well. If it were thinner, the print might break loose from the bed during printing, because of the 40 degree angled tube that fits into the nozzle of the Dust Buster.

Most printers I know of can print an overhang at up to 45 degrees off of vertical. This angle of 40 degrees should work fine.

The indentation of the lettering is deeper than I'd like, but Cura seems to ignore features under 0.5mm thick. I used a Sans-Serif font in FreeCAD to avoid small details that Cura would disregard. Note: FreeCAD's True-Type fonts, available for many uses, are in the FreeCAD installation folder.

This cube is the 2x2 of square ones. It looks and seems easy, but ZAM! You can't solve it.

Assembly is self- explanatory. Print 3 regular edges, 2 edge As, one of each core, 4 middle pices, and a pin (if you think you're a pro cuber, then print 8 edge As instead of 3 regular edges, and 2 edge As). Like my other cubes, insert the pin into the tapered core and put on all the pices. Glue and insert the end of the pin into the other core. Let dry. Enjoy!

description.text:
Have you ever wanted to modify your replicator, but didn't know how? This is the answer! Print out this dandy contraption, and easilly modify your machine to your heart's content!

(the lego used in this thing has been made by canadaduane and his trilego.)

To install this thing on your printer, first turn it off. Then take the appropriate sized allen wrench, and remove the fan in front of the extruder. There should be 2 plastic spacers between the fan and heat sink. Replace the one on the left with the lego rail. Put back together, and enjoy!

Works on replicator 1 and 2.

description.text:
This is the extruder I built for Scalable CoreXY v2: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1829772

I printed the handle using PETG and the body is printed in natural PLA. It is slightly wider than NEMA 17 because I wanted to leave the design open to possibility of changing the 2020 mount direction in the future if necessary.

It uses the same 11mm gear, bearing, and spring from MK7/8 that came with HICTOP printer. Four mounting to NEMA17 motor, it uses 3x m3x5mm, and one m3x25mm. One M4x16mm bolt and nut (inch equivalent I had lying around) is used to fix the bearing to the handle.

NOTE: for 1.75mm Filament

description.text:
My son wanted to be a spider for Halloween. So I 3d printed some LED lit eyes. I modeled them in Fusion 360 and printed them using my dual extruder MakerGear M2. The eye can be lit with a 3mm LED and a watch battery, no other electronics needed. I liked them so much I made a creepier version for myself. The base can be sewn to fabric using the recesses in the base. The base was dual extruded 3d printed with black ABS and HIPS as a support material which was later dissolved away. I uploaded the models to Thingiverse.

CR1620 watch battery and 5mm LED needed for lighting

Eye models and Iris can be dual extruded or printed separately and attached later.

Base should work with breakaway support as well but may require some sanding as its a tight fit.

print_settings.Notes:: The fit between the carriages and the plates is a tiny bit wobbly, not bad enough for me to worry.  If you want to tighten it up, you might print the carriage "vertically" instead of on its side - that way you'd avoid mating a (less precise/repeatable) z tolerance to the xy tolerances in the tab-slot.  There's a "plateGap" variable in the .scad that you can use to adjust the tightness of fit.  The horizontal (default) print orientation probably makes stronger hole walls, but that's not too critical in this application.

description.text:
I wanted a top-loading filament spool roller solution to go in a dry box (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1359419 http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:961881), looked at several existing designs and decided to make my own to optimize a few things for my situation/tastes. Primarily, I wanted it as thin as practical - so I located the "spool keeper" plastic on the inside of the spool, it sticks out about 2mm from the bearing - not enough to rub the filament on the spool, but enough to keep the spool from sliding off the bearing. I also wanted a one piece roller solution - located down in the dry box it's going to be fiddly enough without having to position separate rollers. It's not a universally adjustable design, but you can print different width locating plates, and a single size of roller arms should handle a pretty wide variety of spool diameters.

This design makes 4 easy to print pieces that assemble to hold 4 608 bearings as a spool roller. The bearings are held on by 5/16x1.25" bolts, a couple of washers and a nylock nut - 8mm hardware should also work, though 8x30s might be just a little short to work with nylocks, and 8x40 will stick out almost 9mm. (If you want to use 8x30s, you should probably tweak the .scad to make the carriage arms ~1.7mm thinner.)

The same configuration could be printed as a single piece per spool, and wouldn't be too challenging to print, but then when it's not in use it will be big and bulky to store. The separate pieces can be mixed/matched to work with whatever new spools need to go in the drybox next. You could also print substitutes for the 5/16" hardware, but, why? It's solid, reliable, cheap enough, and readily available. PHIL http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:996398 is your fully printable alternative, but I trust the metal hardware a bit more, especially during an 18 hour print. Also, living down inside a dry box, nobody would see a cute smiley face if YAFR had one.

Minor update: added another notch in the bottom of the carriage to let plates be attached between spool rollers, so several roller sets can be positively located relative to each other. Just print the same spreader plates, but sized as you like for spacing between your spools. For the hardware I'm using, 50mm sized spreader plates between the spools seems just far enough.

Also, a note about filament spool sizes: they vary. I just finished one roll of Hatchbox white that worked just fine all the way through on 56mm spacers, but its replacement roll of Hatchbox white is on a slightly wider spool which falls off when using those spacers. Since the bearings are 7mm wide and this spool just barely falls off, I'm printing some new 61mm spacers to hold the new spool of white.

Printer:

FlashForge Dreamer

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.18mm

Infill:

15%

Notes:

ABS, standard print settings, no heavy stress locations to worry about.

Me, personally, I print the two small plates at once, then print the longer arms one at a time - I think you get better layer bonding if you don't try to print too much at one time.

The fit between the carriages and the plates is a tiny bit wobbly, not bad enough for me to worry. If you want to tighten it up, you might print the carriage "vertically" instead of on its side - that way you'd avoid mating a (less precise/repeatable) z tolerance to the xy tolerances in the tab-slot. There's a "plateGap" variable in the .scad that you can use to adjust the tightness of fit. The horizontal (default) print orientation probably makes stronger hole walls, but that's not too critical in this application.

Assemble as you like it...

Parts list:

2 "plates"
2 "carriages"
4 608 bearings
4 bolts 5/16x1.25" or 8mm
8 washers
4 nylock nuts

Assemble a bolt-bearing-washer / washer-nylock nut to each carriage hole, then tighten the nylock nut down until the bolt just stops spinning freely. The bearings go on the same side of each carriage, if you want your spool to roll freely.

The plates go flat-side down, then the two "carriages" sit on top, tab-A slot-B style.

I designed this frame to sit inside the spool so that it takes up minimal space in the drybox. If you want a wider/more stable stance, you can widen the plate and flip the bearings around to the inside.

Open SCAD

The default settings work for a (my?) Hatchbox 1kg spool, the only two things you should need to change are bearingSpacing to accommodate larger/smaller spool diameters, and plateCtoC to work with thicker/thinner spools. Those are the numbers that get marked on the parts. If you leave the other parameters alone, then the parts should be interchangeable, and ones you're not currently using can be stored flat in a relatively small space.

The numbers printed on the bearing holders are the "design distance" between the bearings (bearingSpacing in the customizer), iff you leave the pillow block outer angle at 0.

The ranges in the Customizer should all make good interchangeable parts. If you need something bigger/smaller, you can open up Roller.scad and edit other parameters to make bigger/smaller designs work, but you may need to sacrifice interoperability with the parts that the customizer is making.

comments.text: Printed up a few of these and bought the 5/16" hardware at Lowe's. One thing I didn't realize until later in the assembly is to put a washer between the head of the bold and the bearing, otherwise tightening the bolt too much makes the bearing not turn so great. Once built, though, it's solid. I printed some 60mm and 65mm spacers, and will probably print a few 53mm spacers between spools so I can pack them close together in my dry boxes. (again, thanks for the OpenSCAD model!!)

Thank you.

Growlers are awesome. Instead of recycling beer cans or bottles you take your growler to your favorite brew pub to get it refilled over and over again. Not saying that recycling bottles or cans is bad, just that bypassing the whole recycling thing all together is even better. Besides, fresh beer on tap is always better than canned or bottled.

I am fortunate to live near several craft breweries so I always keep a couple empty growlers in the car in case I have the opportunity to stop by and get them filled with an interesting and/or delicious brew.

The problem is that, over time, bouncing around in the car the ceramic will tend to chip the glass so they won't seal anymore. At that point you have to buy a whole new growler which defeats the point and costs money. If you close the cap it won't chip but, it'll shorten the life of the seal and if there's any moisture trapped inside critters will likely grow and spoil your delicious beverage.

This is a vented protective cap to extend the life if your growlers. Not necessary, but it would probably be appropriate to print this in beer filament if you have it.

remixed_from.title: MP Select Mini X Gantry Support System

title: MP Select Mini X Gantry Support Bearing Holder Adjusted

description.text:
An adjusted version of the bearing holder for user FDM_Guru's X Gantry Support System for the Monoprice MP Select Mini. This version puts the holder (and hence the shaft) 1.5mm further from the gantry (away from the edge of the printer). I found this was required to get the shaft to align with the hole in the bolt-over side panel.

Also, a small cap to fit over the top end of the shaft, for safety.

name = keaton
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/imgRsJWX2F4

Communion Cup Holder
D-1 (center of hole from bracket side - 5 mm)
D-2 (center of hole from bracket side - 10 mm)
D-3 (center of hole from bracket side - 12 mm)

Just a simple gadget for the busy shopper. A trolley token with an easy grip to remove it when finished.
It can be fitted to a keyring so it is always handy.
I have included the plain 123d file so that anyone can customise their print - not everyone will appreciate the word moose on their trolley key!

Printer:

xyz davinci 1.0A

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

30%

Notes:

Printed in PLA
I used the honeycomb infill option
probably wont need any help such as pritt as mine stuck like the proverbial to a blanket

One circle
One isosceles triangle
One half circle

A trip to the british mint website to get the size of a one pound coin
then i extruded the drawn shapes to the right thickness (3.15 mm) centred them length ways the moved them till they overlapped and looked ok and combined them.

I then made a 3mm rad octagon and centered that close to the grip end for the keyring hole then added raised text.
et voila...

description.text:
EN: Savonius wind turbines are a type of vertical-axis wind turbine (VAWT), used for converting the force of the wind into torque on a rotating shaft. The turbine consists of a number of aerofoils, usually—but not always—vertically mounted on a rotating shaft or framework, either ground stationed or tethered in airborne systems.
Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Savonius_wind_turbine

FR: Le rotor de Savonius est une éolienne à axe vertical. Elle a été inventée par l'ingénieur finlandais Sigurd Savonius en 1924 et a été brevetée en 1929.
Rotor de Savonius
Le fonctionnement du rotor de Savonius est basé sur un couple aérodynamique induit par la déflexion de l'écoulement sur les pales.

https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rotor_de_Savonius

title: Poseidon Guide (Filament guide for Wanhao i3, top-mounted, needs PTFE tube)

description.text:
A very simple modification of the in-game Poseidon statue. I removed the trident (which surprisingly was a separate object anyway) and made a small hole at the bottom for the screw, as well as some room for a PTFE tube.

I've now mounted it atop the printer, where the two holes for the spool holder are.

It's not perfect, the filament is actually too close to the frame, so I need to find a way to move Poseidon a bit outward, but it's better than having the filament at a 90° angle, or scraping across the frame.

The PTFE tube probably needs something to hold it in place - doublesided tape, or this gum-like post-glue stuff I used.

Also, I used a screw that was a bit too long, but in the end it's better that way - the figure can turn with the filament, lean forward and such.

Feel free to improve it. Just don't sell it or claim it as your own - the figure belongs to the makers of Bioshock.

title: Arduino Leonardo slim case with mounting tabs

description.text:
Just added some mounting tabs to this already excellent project. I found that the studs going through the holes in the Leonardo PCB were just ever so slightly too tight, so I had to cut them just a tiny bit down to get a good fit all the way around. Also, there is a big decoupling capacitor behind the power connector that is blocking for the lid to properly close because of the "cut-out walls" around the analog pin connector.
So if I were to print this again, I'd tweak the design further by shaving 0.2mm off the PSB support studs and make a cutout for that big capacitor.
Apart from that, this is a great design from the original designer, kudos! Love the little reset button.

Prints with no supports, used normal settings on Ultimaker 2+.

Compact bearing spinner can be used as a toy or a fidget (good for nervous hands) with following

Pros

  • Compact size fits more hands
  • High resolution of .stl files for smooth curves
  • Rounded edges for better feeling
  • Smart and mature design
  • You can sell your prints because of friendly license

1. Bearings

You need four 608 (single-row radial ball) bearings. Cheap ones seems to be sufficient. Quality bearings spin better (SKF® shoud be the best). Brand is more important than ABEC class. Hybrid ceramic bearing bring incredible spinning time.

  • 608 (without dust shield - visible balls) OK
  • 608 ZZ / 2Z (dust shield on both sides) OK
  • 608 2RS (sealed) worse but usable

Where to find bearings?

  • Skateboard shop
  • Sport shop with Inline skates
  • Specialized shop with bearings
  • Somewhere on the internet

How to prepare bearings?

I recommend to wash cheap bearings before use with fine-grained lubricant like WD40 to ged rid of factory vaseline and get lower friction i.e. longer spin time 20s+. Spray and spin the bearing few times guarantee the best result. Only downside is little bit noise when spinning. Sloppy wash brings some compromise.

2. Print

Print 1x spinner body and 2x bearing caps for center bearing or 8x caps to cover all of them.
Recommended Print Settings:
Infill: 20%
Resolution: 0.2 - 0.1
Perimeters: 3
Solid layers: 3
Supports: No

3. After Print

  • Press one bearing into center hole first through top side of the print
  • After that press rest of them (use sand paper if necessary or soften holes by heat before press)
  • Add caps
  • Share your print
  • Enjoy ;)

Spinning Leaderboard

1. 3:17 - Daniel Goee (odessa2) https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SOE0dpjTfeI
2. 2:03 - Daniel Goee (odessa2) https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RuMT3iZAdrs

title: Lulzbot Mini wibbly wobbly, timey wimey spool arm upgrade

description.text:
Story goes, I had a 5/16x2-1/2 bolt and a hand full of 608 skate board bearings laying around that weren't earning their keep so I decided to put them to work. Never really had a problem with this on the Mini but I noticed spool holders with bearings are a hot topic.

Wow, what a difference.

This is a horrible design but, it works.By allowing the spool to float and pivot as the extruder moves through the XYZ build envelope it reduces the stress on the filament resulting in a smoother, more consistent finished product.

It's ugly but, unless the first prototype screws up on me I probably won't bother to refine or make it pretty. Please feel free to remix.
This is mostly mashed up geometry from MPCNC and Lulzbot's open source meshes with a little love thrown in.

print_settings.Notes:: If you use the separate shroud and support STLs, print the shroud at 60-70% infill, and the supports at thin and sparse as you can get away with.

title: Yet another MK8 blower fan shroud  ;-)  with inductive sensor mount

description.text:
This is a basic fan shroud/duct to mount a 5015 blower onto a MK7/MK8 Stepstruder-class hotend/extruder assembly. This one was designed with my "bowdenized" version in mind, but it should work with standard MK8 extruders. It mounts in place of the two standoffs/spacers normally found between the cold end's fan and the heat sink.

Includes a mounting ring for an 18 mm diameter proximity sensor/probe (I use LJ18A3-8-Z/BX ).

An .AMF is included that contains the shroud and custom supports placed together properly, with settings that should make them print somewhat similar to what your slicer might have done with its automatic supports, plus settings to make the shroud print nice and dense.

You may have to adjust the height of your heatblock to get the bottom to line up with the bottom of the shroud.

If you haven't already done so, you MUST insulate your heatblock. I use "ceramic cloth" strips and liberal amounts of kapton tape on both the hotend and around the center of the shroud. I recommend printing this with ABS or something else that has a high glass transition temperature.

Also take special care to get the bottom of the shroud level with your bed when you put things back together. It should nominally be about 5 mm above the tip of the nozzle, though the exact difference in height depends on the length of your throat/heatbreak and that of your nozzle. Your probe tip will likely be perhaps 4 mm above the tip of the nozzle (so just a bit below the shroud).

Note that there may be a slight interference between the lower probe mounting nut and the little support column to its right. Just lean the probe sideways slightly as you thread the lower nut into place.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

70%

Notes:

You will want good bridging performance with your chosen filament to print this. Print slow and not too hot, and point a desk fan or two at the print.

Pay close attention to how your slicer handles bridging, lest it make some wrong assumptions about thread direction.

If you use the separate shroud and support STLs, print the shroud at 60-70% infill, and the supports at thin and sparse as you can get away with.

Have your hobby knife handy, just in case. :-)

When you mount the fan, trim the little square bit off of the narrow side of the fan, and wrap the end with a single, narrow layer of kapton, Scotch/cello tape, masking tape, or something else of similar thickness to create a "gasket" between the fan and the shroud's inlet.

Use M4 screws and nuts to mount the fan to its bracket. You may find it useful to put the nuts on the inside (e.g. left) of the bracket, and add a drop of superglue to each nut just before you tighten the screws down. You may need to add a couple of washers under the head of the top-front screw, to keep it from poking too far through the nut.

I used Blender. :-)

In addition to the fan shroud and its supports, the .blend contains objects representing the inductive probe, X carriage plate, hotend/nozzle, mounting block and other things, to help me with layout and measurements when creating the should.

Some of these parts came from coelestinian's QU-BD model (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:39299).

The "OpenHardware" fan guard therein is Mak-a-face's model (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:198400) I believe.

author: Twinsmaker

title: X-Axis Linear Rail Carriage Adapter for 3D Systems Cube3

description.text:
This is an adapter that mounts to the X-axis linear rail carriage of the 3D Systems Cube3. The stock extruder carriage (see the second picture) also includes a "belt gripper" that cinches a section of the GT2 belt against the linear rail carriage. Without this "gripper", the belt just spins and doesn't move the carriage.

It's probably not very useful by itself, but it can serve as a base for whatever extruder mount you want to use on your Cube3.

I didn't feel like creating the gripper part from scratch, so I used netfabb to slice that part off of daGHIZmo's model and just imported it directly into OpenSCAD.

Requires MCAD and GDMUtils, and the included "raw_belt_gripper.stl" model.

MCAD:
https://github.com/openscad/MCAD

GDMUtils:
https://github.com/revarbat/snappy-reprap/blob/master/GDMUtils.scad

title: Raspberry Pi Frame for VESA Mount

description.text:
This is a frame I designed for mounting a Raspberry Pi 2 or 3 to a 100mm VESA mount -- a common mount that should fit to the back of many monitors and TVs. (DISCLAIMER: I measured the VESA mount on the back of my monitor at closer to 98mm than 100mm, strangely, so I designed this part to fit that. It fits perfectly on my monitor, so I'd think it'll fit yours. But please let me know if it doesn't work for you; I can easily produce another version that's a true 100mm.)

The Pi mounts to the frame using the inner set of holes -- use 4x M2.5 screws with matching hex nuts, as shown. You can mount the Pi to the frame in either of two orientations (right side up or upside down), and of course the VESA mount holes are a square, so you can rotate the whole frame to please yourself!

description.text: Simple cutlery drainer with 3 compartments

Printer:

Dagoma discovery 200

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0,2

Customizable Longworth Chuck for wood lathes:

It is done in OpenSCAD for complete control of variables and the ability to export to DXF for CNC, laser cut, or template making.

v4 - fixed spiral width for bolts (chuck jaws), added animate feature
v3 - added adapter mounting holes

adapterhole=size of hole for adapter
adapterholenum=number of holes - enter 0 for none
adapterholedist=hole distance from center
adapterholeangle=change the rotation of the holes to suit your needs

Variable Explanations (every length is inches):

chuckdia=diameter of the entire longworth chuck
chuckthick=if you are going to CNC/laser, this will help determine thickness of stock

adapterdia=adapter for the chuck to the lathe
offsetedge=distance from the edge to the outer rim of the arc
centerholedia=center hole for axle of chuck

washerthick=if you are using a washer this may come into play
boltdia=bolts size for the chuck jaws

numberarcs=how many spirals or jaws
arcangle=maximum of 90 - adjust this for odd chuckdia

numberholes=number of finger holes
fingerholedia=diameter of the finger hole
fingerrotate=if you need to adjust the finger hole placement coinciding with the number of arcs

res=resolution of arcs and circles

This project was done in 2016.10.30.nightly in order to process the correct rotate_extrude function.

This model can also be built with 3 modules that only have the arcs, include fingerholes, and include a seat for the chuck adapter with fingerholes.

I used the lathe chuck adapter I made on OpenSCAD as well to mount to the lathe itself: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1860359

Once you like your design, make sure to File>Export>Export As STL

Create a new OpenSCAD file or open the OpenSCAD DXF Export.scad file and make sure to find the path of your STL. You can use projection to cut a layer and then Export to DXF and open in your favorite CAD or vector program.

File>Export>Export As DXF Opening your model in a vector drawing program or CAD software Animated version to show functionality of of chuck Gluing pieces together with spindle adapter. Nut is embedded within the layers. Using a threaded nut insert for the piece attached to the adapter. I used epoxy to seal the threaded nut in place. The center hole in this set is slightly larger than the outer pieces of the chuck in order to accept the insert. The bolts attaching the lathe adapter are flat pan head and I countersunk the chuck holes by hand. Added 2 coats of varnish for protection after sanding...

comments.text: This is great!  I have been turning wood for years and have recently just got my first CNC router up and running.  Cannot wait to customize and cut my own Longworth.  Thanks for all the effort you have put into this!

description.text: Drop - in replacement lid for the orangeRx UHF (openLRSng) 1W JR case lid. This changes the 'stick out' SMA connector on the factory case lid for one that is parallel to the case, reducing the thickness of the transmitter with antenna attached. Use this to replace the existing lid, for best performance replace the existing lid's countersunk screws with flat head ones. This also comes with the spacer required to hold the PCB in place inside the case.

title: Modification fan nozzle Prusa i3 MK2

description.text: Modification of the fan nozzle. Temperature printing PLA does not fall on the second layer.

comments.text: Do you have this file in a .dxf or .scad file? I need to modify this piece for my printer because the bottom of the nozzle on the hot end I have is about 5mm lower than what it is supposed to be so the fan is blowing on the heater block instead of the print itself.
comments.author: iguanahotsauce

comments.text: I made this earlier today. I haven't seen any improvement in temperature stability. It still fluctuates between 206 - 213 while printing PLA.
comments.author: baballuci

comments.text: @baballuci I would suggest looking to change you PID settings for the extruder. I modified mine and am to the point it fluctuates +- .5* C during very long prints. I am still using the original fan shroud.
comments.author: baballuci

comments.text: Yeah, that's what i did in the end.
comments.author: bcheck555

comments.text:
It helped me. At full speed the fan had a thermal runaway.
I know that the software can reduce the fan speed, but after this modification, the problem with me gone.
comments.author: baballuci

comments.text: Have you printed and installed this yet? Upload a photo!
comments.author: Drazen

comments.text: Yes, I printed and installed. I tested on the PLA 50x50x2 mm and the temperature on the second layer has not fallen as much as 1*C and printing was perfect. photos added ;-)
comments.author: Drazen

title: Hudson's Taco Truck
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text: My 4 year old looooves taco's and recently we printed out some taco holders,(http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:406738) and they work awesome, but they hold three tacos.My son thought they were the coolest thing ever and saw some of the taco trucks while we were tinkering around on thingiverse, and his one empty taco holder was just bugging him. He said he wanted his own taco truck, that looked like our three holders, with TWO places for tacos. Then he goes, "and obviously a place for my cheese" (hes very specific for 4).

Printer Brand:

Robo 3D

Printer:

R1 ABS + PLA Model

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

low

Infill:

15%

Notes:

We printed this with PLA and it took about 3 and half hours.

We make our projects educational while working on them, ie Mom doesn't do all the work. I handed him the ruler and told him to measure our taco holders so we knew how big our shapes had to be. Then we converted our numbers from CM to MM because Mom forgot how to do it [wink]
We sketch out together what our truck will look like, then break up what shapes we see in the truck. We call them tinkercad shapes, and photoshop shapes. We then made our vector image of the back of the taco holder on its side in photoshop. I had him convert the files using online-convert.com and import it (if I leave the windows open for him, he does this by himeself), then he sat on my lap and directed me about what shapes would make the truck according to his "map". With a little help placing the shapes I ask him why this needs to be a hole and other structural questions, such as how to use different shapes so we have less supports. How to find the "invisible shapes"  that turn into supports. What shapes are stronger and won't break as easily. How do we make this so it takes less plastic. Then we play the guessing game, how many hours will it take to print at low, med, high, resolutions? Then we write down our guesses and see who wins. Winner gets the smarties.

• Measure
  • Convert Measurements
  • Draw the truck
  • Decifer all shapes: negative space shapes, photoshop shapes, tinkercad shapes
  • Vector Image
  • File conversion and importing
  • Tinkercad. Applying our shapes. Follow a design.
  • Prepare for printing
  • Guessing game, estimating time
  • PRINT and PRIZE (who wins the time estimate gets the smarties)

• math
  • metric system
  • engineering
  • computer science
  • integrating skills
  • design
  • creativity
  • technology
  • planning

title: Remix of Center Bed Leveler for MPSM for Smaller Gaps

description.text:
A remix of auralgasm's "Center Bed Leveler for MP Select Mini" for re-leveling (ratcheting up) a warped print bed.

Reason for remixing

The original design would not fit under my print bed as I had lowered my printer's bed about as far as it could go to install an aftermarket nozzle on the hot end. This redesign is intended for others in my circumstance who have less clearance under their print bed's. I significantly reduced the poly count of the geometry to make it easier to modify (I had to do a lot of trial and error to find something that worked). Differences in clearance height is shown in attached pictures.

Notes

Print in ABS or PETg, PLA is NOT recommended if you ever plan on heating the bed. A lower layer height is recommended to preserve the screw threads. I used 0.1mm for my layer height, but a multiple of the printer's full-step length on the z-axis (0.04375 mm for the MP Select Mini) should work better (thanks SPampel).

Make sure to avoid the bed's wiring and thermistor when using this!

comments.text: Layer height on the Monorpice Select Mini / Malyan M200 should be a multiple of 0.04375 mm. Source: https://hackaday.io/project/12696-monoprice-select-mini-electro-mechanical-upgrades

title: Body for McDonalds' Trolls' DJ Suki

description.text:
McDonalds is giving with each Kid's Meal a Trolls movie Toy which happens to be just the head of the troll to stick on a pencil top.
Since the whole movie is about how the Bergens enjoy eating Trolls I found quite amusing to give the kids bodyless trolls to play with.... lol
Anyhow, we just came out of the movies from watching it and grabed a box for my son to eat at home. His expression when he opened the box and found the head but could not find the rest of the troll was not a pleased one. So Mom told him "Don't worry, Dad will give her a body".
So I got back to my computer and did a quick hack with blender. Nothing fancy. Then I printed it and painted it. And I was back with a full Troll for him to play with.
Is not much, but if any out there find themselves in the same situation, you can print this little Suki or use it as a base for your own troll.

Printer:

Mini Kossel

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.10mm

Infill:

full for the first 10mm and then 10%

Notes:

I've printed it with a 0,4 nozzle and 3 perimeters, the z layer was 0.10mm high and for the first 10mm I've printed it solid to give it some weight on the feet, the rest was printed with 10% fast honeycomb infill. I'm sure I could get away with much less but this way I'm certain it will survive my son's playfullness ;P
I've lowered 0,5mm the whole mesh so the feet would be flat, I've could have fixed the mesh instead, but as I said I was in a hurry.
I've used supports and I had to add some extra support on the left arm since it's not attached to the body besides at the shoulder.
At this resolution it printed fine in about 3hrs at 100mm/s

description.text:
The Sons of the Harpy were an underground insurgency group fighting the rule of Daenerys Targaryen over Meereen, composed of former slavers. They took their name from the harpy, the traditional heraldic symbol of the slave-masters in the Ghiscari cities of Slaver's Bay, and the Ghiscari Empire before them. They concealed their identities by wearing golden masks with horned faces resembling harpies.(gameofthroneswiki)
Using the source file, I scaled it up, and printed in 2 pieces. I had sculpted a pattern on it with Blender.

description.text:
I recently purchased this charging station which had an area to charge an Apple watch:

https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01KYFPXY8/ref=oh_aui_search_detailpage?ie=UTF8&psc=1

I wanted it to work with my pebble time, so I designed this adapter for it. You can see a video for it here:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bix2rpQQA0c

There may be other bamboo charging stations available with a similar watch area with the round hole interface like the one here. Also, you could print this without the round peg on the back side and glue just the square portion to almost any other stand.

And don't mess with the cheap chinese charging cables as a replacement for the official ones from Pebble - they are complete garbage.

print_settings.Notes:: Used Hatchbox Copper ABS

description.text:
I had some trouble with the original model with supports so I decided to try my hand at breaking the model in sections.

The top part has two holes under the brim for connecting to the middle half.

The middle half has two holes for connecting to the top and two holes for the feet to insert.

The feet are printed with small pegs on top to slide into the middle part.

The pegs on the feet and the peg inserts for connecting the body together are slightly smaller then the holes, you may need to do some light sanding or finishing to get them to slide properly.

I supplied two different peg inserts, one is 4.6mm x 9mm the other is 4.6mm by 8.5mm, The holes for these pegs are 4.8mm x 9.8mm (was original intended to be 5x10, but had a small mix up)

I am considering changing the feet so that it has holes as well allowing for a customized peg insert there as well.

Hope it prints well for everyone.

This is a simple snap-fit joints library based on "Snap-Fit Joints for Plastics - A Design Guide" by Bayer MaterialScience LLC .
http://fab.cba.mit.edu/classes/S62.12/people/vernelle.noel/Plastic_Snap_fit_design.pdf

The idea is to correctly dimension the snap-fit joints, according to the elongation at break that can withstand.
-The global variable eps define the material (e.g. PLA: eps=0.03; ABS: eps=0.06)
-The dimension are the same reported on Design Guide. For simple cantilever snap it is also possible to define h or y (see figure)
-The value of K2 or K1 used in Ring snap could be taken from Fig 10 of guide (but the default K=2 should be ok).

I have also added some simple example on the use of the library. I also printed the cable clamp, and it works well.
it is suggested to print snap-fit cantilever on the XY printer plane.

Bug Fix: 0.35
on the basis of the shanemgrey reporting:
on RSnapY I have added a check to avioid interference of lobes during closure; on RRSnappY I have added a check to avioid overlapped lobes. also the snapLib.Example files is updated.

New version: 0.30
Added Scale factor f to reduce the calculate value h or y (this maintain the snap on unbreakable zone when f>1)
added function Hsnap and Snap to calculate the snap H or Y for cantilever snap (useful to define the snap bores)

Between filamentdrive and hotend the K8200 has a thermal insulation made of teflon. The filament is heated in a fairly large and undefined area depending on temperature and feeding speed. In addition, the volume of the hole in the teflon cylinder increases with pressure and with temperature. Both factors mean that in slic3r the retrack must be set to a few millimeters. Nevertheless flow of filament does not stop. It's not possible to produce multiple parts in one operation without blobs and threads. Replacing the filament is also a problem. Sometimes it works, sometime it sticks in the extruder so the extruder must be taken apart. I shortened the original teflon cylinder and replaced it by an actively cooled aluminum heatsink. The area with the largest temperature gradient is now reduced to a few millimeters. The retrack can be reduced to 1 mm in slic3r to interrupt the flow of filament. Also replacement of filament is now easy to do by turning left the big gearwheel (while the extruder is still heated) until the filament can be pulled out by hand. http://k8200.jimdo.com/extruder/

p.s. the banner is a reworking of the banner of fractalnoise terminator.

Algebra and Negative Integer Fun!  
This balance is intended to help visualize the use of negative integers or that negative one is less than zero. Weights placed on the outer pans represent negative integers, weights placed on the inner pans represent positive integers, which makes it possible to visualize an equation like: (-1)+(+1)=0+0 where the = sign is the tower..  
The full scale version has a 10" Top Beam, however I do not have access to a Makerbot so the printed version is half scale at this time, which is really small on a low-res reprap.  Hopefully I can print a full scale version in color some time in the future (The district I teach in doesn't have a 3D printer, however a district we mentored in FRC last year may be getting a Replicator 2).  I didn't add plastic chips since I intended to use pennies as number weights.  
This balance is meant to be easily sliced and printed, and there is also a dwg vector file for a laser cut version in the future.  I had designed it to be easily made out of one 1/8" acrylic 16"x20" sheet for schools that only have laser cutters as well.

Bill of Materials:
(1) Base
(2) Towers
(1) Tower Clip
(1) Top Beam
(1) Top Beam Lock
(2) Mid Beams
(1) Lower Beam
(8) Clips
(4) Pans
(4) Pan Clips
(2) Pointers Instructions to build:
  • Place Lower Beam between two tower halves, then place the tower into the base.
  • Put the tower clip over the top of the tower to lock it in place.
  • Place the pointers in from each square in the middle (there is a version of the pointers with a hole in the middle for a bolt if you wish).
  • Place top tower on top before bolting (optional) the pointer together.
    5, Put on the first two clips joining the mid to lower beam on the top set of holes.
  • Put on the next two clips joining the top beam to the mid beam at the fulcrum point.
  • Add the pan clips to the pans by gently squeezing the clips
  • Add clips to the outer holes on the mid and lower beam and add the pans onto those clips
  • Add the top beam lock if needed to keep the top beam from rocking
    • You can use a variety of weights for this balance, pennies work nicely, or you can print out some plastic chips. Tip - If you have fitment issues, scale up the tower clip, and base a tiny bit (varies by printer). You can also scale down the pointer a tiny bit. Weights on the outer pan represent negative integers, weights on the inner pans represent positive integers the tower represents the equal sign if all is balanced. Have fun learning!
Adjusting your Z-Axis endstop has not been easier.

description.text:
Fancy yourself a masochist? Or perhaps you are a sadist? Either way you'll love the pain and deprivation provided by the all new iTorture. Take yours or a friends iPhone 4 and drop it into the tightly constrained iHole at the top of the iTorture and let the iMissery begin. Once inside the iTorture's magical Spheroid inner cavity you're really going to be taking advantage of this never before seen special regular hexahedron. Boom.
Oh and one more thing. The iTorture has a special viewing port on its bottom face, just big enough to give you the illusion of control while trying to coax the iPhone from its truncated cube prison. Want to up the stakes. Try the iTorture Extreme for an even more challenging experience.
100% infill to make it nice and strong.

comments.text: Acetone will not make ABS plastic brittle, but softer and more flexible. If you add enough, you can dissolve it, but then it will creep into any cavities of the phone - not a thing you want to happen. When printing with PLA, acetone doesn't do anything. You can make PLA brittle with water, but again, you don't want any water in your phone.

comments.text: Sorry for my late response. The 3D printed hexagonal part is for extending M8 screw hexagonal head (part is glued to the screw). The reason is to extend movable screw part in "rotating knob". I used the classic M8 screw and I did not want to make it entirely from metal or use more glued nuts. 3D printing was faster :-). title: MidiRex Box
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a 3d printable box for your MidiRex Midi looper circuit board. Midirex is a great project at midisizer.com, it is like a guitar looper pedal, but it is just for MIDI, not audio. Play your synths with a midi controller, record a loop on the Midirex, and then it can play the loop of notes while you change the sound. Peter Kvitek, the designer of the electronics, has PCB's and programmed processors for sale through his website. Parts are from Digikey or Mouser, and there is a BOM with the parts to order.

MidiRex Box design by Ben Milner 2016
MidiREx PCB , circuit, and software design by Peter Kvitek
More info at http://midisizer.com

Build Options

There are two versions of the top half of the box to choose from, one has the stock options of LED's, and jacks, this will fit your already built MidiRex, the other, "Panel Mount" version box design has more robust parts substitutions from the original design, if you are building a new Midirex, or wish to modify your stock version.

"Panel mount" Version substitutions:

LED's: The track and select LED's are 5mm LED's, not 3mm. I recommend diffused LED, rather than water clear, they are easier to see from an angle. I used different colors to jog my memory which track is which, and tailored the resistors that limit the current to the LED's for each color, by hooking up a 5v power supply to the LED, through a 5k pot (used as a variable resistor) and a series 220 ohm resistor, and then dialed in the brightness that was good for each LED. I recommend going on the bright side, as the LED's are at half brightness when the track is on, and only at full brightness when the track is selected, and on. Might not be a bad idea to socket the resistors.

Note, the MIDI in and out activity LED's are the stock 3mm.

Footswitch jack: I used a panel mount stereo 1/4" jack (digikey pn# SC1317-ND) rather than 1/8", for more robustness, and the footswitches are more common in the music world. This is on wires, soldered in where the 1/8" jack would have soldered to the board.

DC power jack: I used a metal, panel mount DC jack (Digikey PN# EJ502A-ND), for better reliability, as well bringing the DC plug closer to the surface of the box. Some DC plugs didn't fit way down in the box. Lastly, the panel mount DC jack, allowed me to reverse the polarity of the 9V DC, so I could use the common Boss (guitar pedal) style 9v power supplies, those are 2.1mm, tip negative, whereas the original PCB power jack is for 9v, tip positive power supplies.

Extra Parts (both versions)

Extra parts to order, for either box version:

Switch caps: Whew. This was hard. It was very difficult to find tall switch caps for the tact switches spec'd in the BOM, the E-Switch TL1100F160Q. The nice Eswitch caps that look like they fit don't, they don't snap on, they just sit there loose and fall out. I glued mine on with PVA glue, but a snap would be better. The critical piece of information to finding caps that will fit is that the plunger is 3.3mm square, 3.8mm is a more common size, but those will be loose. The other criteria is the cap needs a little lip right on the bottom, to snap onto the switch plunger. Someone said the C&K caps may fit, but I have not tried them.

My holes are sized for .35" (8.75mm) diameter switch caps, I included an STL to print your own, it may be easier than sourcing them.

Encoder knob: Watch out, the encoder in the BOM has a D shape, 6mm (.236") shaft, not a .25" shaft, so it needs a special knob. I just had the .25" knob, so wrapped electrical tape around the shaft once to make it fit tight.

Display: My display wasn't bright enough, so I made R12, the (only) 68 ohm resistor, that limits current to the display, a straight wire instead. This is safe, because in the datasheet it says the display has onboard current limiting for the backlight, you can give it the straight 5v. I wanted a red display, rather than blue, so I got a red New Haven display from the same series, NHD-0216K1Z-NSR-FBW-L-ND at digikey. They had a few other colors in the series.

Rubber feet: You'll want to get some adhesive rubber feet, or rubber sheet cut to size, so the midirex doesn't scoot around when you start rockin'.

Fasteners: The PCB attaches to the top with 4x #4 sheat metal screws, 3/8" long. These can be the self tapping kind.

The lid attaches to the box with 4x #6 sheet metal screws, 5/8" long. Self tapping is good here, as well.

Printing the Midirex box

This design was an experiment in making labels for the controls as indents on the top panel, which works if you can get detail in your first layer. I had to edit my printer settings, because the first layer is usually extra thick and squished to the plate.

I tried painting the indents, but had a problem with the paint wicking into the gaps in layers and bleeding. If you want to paint, it would help to hit it with some kind of clear coat first, to seal it, like a matte medium, possibly. That would hopefully seal the gaps, while leaving the indents for the letters intact.

A paintless approach is to print the first two layers and then pause the printer (with a pause in the G-code, if you can), and change color. The letters are .6mm deep, so for my printer at .3mm layers, that was 2 layers with the letters cut out, and the 3rd layer prints smooth over them. I had disappointing results with a transparent PLA on top, so recommend an opaque filament for the first two layers, and then something contrasty for the rest of the build. For expert 3d printers, you may be able to get very nice lettering outlines, by slicing the model twice, with different settings for the letter layers, and then your preffered settings for the rest of the model, and then editing the g-code together. The idea, is that you could use one perimeter only, on the letter layers, and get a nicer outline and infill, then switch to a setting that is structural (I used 4 perimeters, for extra strength and weight, but 3 is probably fine).

Print the Top, with a pause for your color change, if you are doing contrasting letters. Take whatever precautions to prevent warping, as a big , thick, flat bottom is the most prone to the corners slowly lifting after a while. Gluestick does it for me, and a heat lamp shining on the work. A brim can help. If just nothing works, try using the brim, and then pausing it after the 2nd layer, and taping the brim down with masking tape. I then home the X and Y axis in case it got bumped, then resume.

Print the Bottom Lid.

This model is optimized for printing on FDM printers, without support. I put in some manual supports for the big MIDI plug holes, these can be cut away. There are thin, temporary plugs to the indented screw holes, this is to be able to print those features by bridging the gap quickly, then the next layer defines the hole. Just drill or cut out these thin plugs after it has printed. Clean out all of the screw holes with theright size tap drill for your screws. Clean out the bottom lid with the right size body drill for your screws. Ream out, or drill out the button holes, to make sure they are very smooth, and the right size for your buttons. This will help the buttons operate smoothly. Any blobs or irregularities will make them bind up. Test the buttons in the holes. Test the footswitch and DC jacks in their holes. Ream out the LED holes, if needed, so they fit a little loose, so the board goes in easy. Clean out the holes in the back panel, a step drill is good to ream out the big MIDI jack holes, regular drill bits for the smaller holes.

The hole for the encoder shaft is slotted, this is to help assembly, because the on/off switch needs to get in its hole somehow, so clean out the encoder slot to give some slop for that part of the assembly. As a side note, you may consider getting rid of the on/off switch, and just hardwire it ON. Test the PCB fit into the top, and the buttons on the pcb. File/ream/drill if necessary. Once the PCB assembly fits nice into the top, screw the PCB into the standoffs with the 4x #4 screws. Put the panel mount jacks, on wires, if you are using the "Panel Mount" version, in. Snap the button caps on, you can support the PCB with your hand, inside, so you aren't bending the PCB, if they are hard to snap in. Screw on the bottom lid, and put on the encoder knob. Loop!

description.text:
Easy 3D Print Halloween Costume: Wayne's World.

Print and glue to your hat. Party Time! Excellent!

For the hat use: waynes-world-logo-hat-logo.stl

This is a Waynes Word logo I hand traced. The geometry on the globe part is a little dicey. The bottom half the lines on the globe are a 3D->2D projection. The top part of the globe where the lines meet was too small to print on my printer, so the lines were (poorly) artificially thickened. They don't quite line up right.

The blender file is in really good shape. The layers 00, 01, ..12 are the letters in order. The bottom bars can be boolean added on or off to your liking.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

100

Notes:

I printed this with a 0.2mm layer. The Z height is 0.8 mm so that will be four layers.

The size of the print is correct for a normal snap-back black hat like Wayne wears in the movie.

HotGlue to hat

Caution: Hot Glue is HOT. You will burn yourself attaching this so be ready.

It is thin enough to just bend to any hat even a floppy one. I glued it in the center and worked out.

WARNING: I use a "high temp hot glue gun" and it was melting/warping the logo. so use VERY little glue if this is what you have.

title: Meritor WABCO Parking Brake Safety Lock
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This device is used to lockout the Parking Brake switch on certain Air Brake equipped Motor Coaches. The locking device houses the brake switch and guards it in the Parked position...a long shank padlock shackle serves to secure the locking device in place. It is mainly used to prevent over zealous pets, or perhaps youngsters from inadvertently releasing the parking brake system. This is not an anti-theft device... It's most practical use is when you stop for fuel...while my wife takes one of the dogs for a rest break...and I'm outside fueling the coach --- we have one puppy left unattended, inside. The air tanks are full, the transmission is in Neutral, sometimes we're on a slight slope --- it would be a bad day to have the coach start rolling away from me while standing on the off-door side...with a fuel nozzle in my hand.

Disclaimer: The designer is not responsible for the suitability of this design. It is not a substitute for wheel chocks, etc... Please refer to your Motor Coach Manufacturer's guidance for safe operation of your Recreational Vehicle.

Revision History:

Version 4 is the current design. I am happy with the fit and finish of this design. I am trying to add a 5th version that will not have the holes for a padlock shackle...but instead have flexible prongs inside to hold the brake control shaft. My first attempt failed due to the easy de lamination of ABS on thin walled structures. I will try again using slightly modified dimensions and nylon filament to see if I can get that model up and running.

Printer:

Flash Forge Creator Pro

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I printed it with 4 outer layers...and 20% triangular infill. Use of raft is totally optional. I had it check when I sliced the model.

Adjusting design for fit

Since the Brake Switch installation may vary from coach to coach...the user may need to remix the design to get the proper fit.

Laser-cut design components for a Newton's cradle/Gauss gun

See assembling instructions at https://youtu.be/IWAIx6-hRZI

For an overview of Gauss guns (and a video of them shattering 3 glass light bulbs) see https://youtu.be/nWyTd7dF0ys

Project designed to help young students learn about energy and its role in creating motion. Energy cannot be created nor destroyed, but it can be transferred between objects and from one form to another. In this case the Newton's cradle and the Gauss gun are the devices used to show how gravity and magnetism (potential energy) help things move (kinetic energy), and how energy, and thus motion, is transferred between objects when they come in contact.

Designed by ECE undergraduate Javier Garcia, advised by Aaron T. Becker at the University of Houston.

The purpose of this project is to demonstrate several forms of energy transfer. The model has two configurations, which are achieved by simply rotating the leg supports. When the curved faces are pointing up the model is in the Newton’s cradle configuration, and it demonstrates the transfer of gravitational potential to kinetic energy. Some balls are placed on the valley and another is placed on one of the higher sides; as the ball rolls down towards the valley it gains speed due to gravity, and when it hits the balls resting its momentum is transferred to the last ball on the opposite side, making it move. Another concept that can be explored here is energy dissipation, primarily through friction, as it can be easily noted that the balls don’t make it all the way to the top again. When the channels are pointing up the model is in the Gauss gun configuration. In this case, a magnet is placed midway along the channel and several balls are attached to only one side of it. Another ball is placed on the side of the gun where there’s nothing attached to the magnet and it’s given a little push. As the ball approaches the magnet its speed is greatly increased, since it’s made out of magnetic material, and as a result when the ball hits the magnet the last ball on the opposite side is sent flying. The lesson here is that the ball that is initially in movement achieves more speed and therefore carries more energy in the Gauss gun than in the Newton’s cradle, thanks to the magnetic potential being greater than the gravitational potential. To better transfer momentum through the balls the magnet is set in a slot to prevent it from moving when the ball impacts, and the model is designed so that multiple Gauss gun stages can be connected to shoot balls at even higher speeds. Objectives After this project students will have a better understanding of the concept of energy and one of the ways it affects objects (motion). They will also better understand how energy is transferred between objects, and transformed (from potential to kinetic energy in this case).

Ask students how devices such as cellphones, cars, appliances, etc. work. Lead them to realize that charged batteries, fuel, electricity from the wall outlet, etc. transfer "something" to the devices in order to make them function. Discuss with them that the "something" is called energy and that energy that is initially stored in one form can be converted to another form in order to produce a change, such as a screen turning on or an object being set into motion. Activity 1: Newton's Cradle Distribute the model sets to the students. It is recommended to not give them the magnets at this point, since it will very likely cause distractions. Tell them how to assemble the model in the Newton's cradle configuration. After they are all done, tell the students to place one ball on one of the sides of the cradle and let go of it. Ask what they think is causing the ball to roll down towards the valley of the cradle. Discuss with them that gravity gives objects the potential to move, giving other examples such as lifting a pencil and letting go of it. Make them realize that as the ball rolls down its speed increases, and that this means that the energy due to gravity is being converted into "motion" energy, which is called kinetic. Afterwards tell the students to place about 3-4 balls in the valley of the cradle and let a ball roll down from one of the sides again. When the moving ball hits the resting balls, the last ball on the opposite side will start moving; discuss that the kinetic energy from the ball rolling down is transferred all the way to the ball on the opposite side when it collides. At this point you can also mention that the second ball in motion doesn't reach the top of the cradle, and that all the balls come to a rest after a while. Ask the students why they think this is the case. Discuss that energy must be leaving the system due to mechanisms such as friction. Mention that friction transforms kinetic energy into thermal energy, or heat. Ask students if they can think of other examples that demonstrates such transformation. Activity 2: Gauss Gun Tell the students to put on their safety glasses and assemble the model in the Gauss gun configuration. Distribute the magnets and have the students discuss for a couple of minutes how they think magnets work. Afterwards, have them place the magnet in the slot in the middle of the gun channel and to put 3-4 balls on one side of it. Tell them to make sure that the balls are aligned and centered, and that no one is right in front of the side of the gun where the balls are. Once that's done they have to hold another ball on the opposite side of the channel, away from the magnet. Tell the students to pay close attention to what happens when the ball is given a little push towards the magnet. After shooting the gun a couple of times, ask them why the ball on the opposite side gains so much more speed compared to the Newton's cradle. Discuss that magnets, just like gravity, give objects the potential to move. Such form of energy is called potential energy, because it's stored in objects and it's transformed into kinetic energy when the objects are released. Also discuss that the magnetic potential in this case is greater than the gravity potential, giving the ball much greater speed as it approaches the resting balls, which explains why the ball all the way in the opposite side gets so much more kinetic energy transferred to it. If there's time, show the students how to connect multiple Gauss gun stages. The balls will shoot farther; discuss that multiple stages give the balls more speed which equals more kinetic energy.

I initially wanted to buy a 3d printer but was not happy with the size so i decided to create and build my own design based on the best of what was out there.
This is a large 3d printer with a print area or build size of approximatly 22" x 16" x 15"or 560mm x 410 x 380mm.
It uses Makerslide linear bearing system http://www.makerslide.com/ for the x, y and z axis.
It is a derivative of the Mendelmax and the Quantum Ordbot.
I am currently building a prototype.
The build is scalable and it is easy to expand the model just like its predecessor the Mendelmax.
send me an email on [email protected] FEATURES:
Large build area 22" x 16" x 15"or 560mm x 410 x 380mm
Aluminium extrusion frame
Makerslide linear V/ rail x,y & z axes
Adjustable belts
12mm threaded rod
Easy assembly
Scaleable
Solid build
No extruding parts
Self replicating Reprap I have utilised several ideas from thingiverse in this build and would like to thank the following for their ideas and inspiration.... Mendelmax by Kludgineer http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:12645

UPDATE 4/9/12 Everything is printing fine, been having good results. have uploaded new sideclamp part (stronger) and alternative nema 23 stepper motor mount(too much play in the original.the only thing i have left to figure out is how to run four standard heat beds off one computer power supply, as at the moment i am only able to heat 1/4 of the build surface area . Any tips? Will upload new video soonish maybe today and show some of the things i have printed. One thing i havent been able to work out and i think is an issue with the printrboard is that i have to pull out the Y-axis end stop plug from the printrboard in order to connect to pronterface i saw on a forum that this may have been identified as a fault on some boards.Not a big issue it just means that i have to manually position the y -axis before starting a print, i am now using "cura" as my slicing program as it seems to be able to slice more complicated parts than slic3r and for a big build area you need a slicer that can handle the job.Thinking of a kickstarter project depending on demand.Oh and check out the new model i uploaded which is printing ATM. I am thinking of designing an alternative spool holder.Oh and i didnt end up using the ABS sidebracketforextruder part.

comments.author: Johno

comments.text: I just thought I would chime in on why I did not choose to pursue Makerslide further on the standard MendelMax. I built a few test bots with it early on, but after experimenting with it I was not really impressed. Part of the problems were definitely related to the first draft parts I was using, but even if you eliminated those problems, I couldn't quite see any benefit. It is more "fiddly" getting everything tightened properly, and it is considerably more expensive than just using cheaper shafting. The friction is probably marginally lower, but certainly not significantly lower. In the end I just could not see any actual benefit that would justify my recommending it or investing further time in developing the parts.
comments.author: kludgineer

comments.text: I almost went for a standard Mendelmax but i needed a larger size printer, in my research i came accross the Ordbot and Makerslide so i thought i would combine them, i originally created a 3d model of the Mendelmax, upsized it and converted the axes. It has been pointed out to me that for this size build or bigger i may need to go on to a larger size extrusion, to maintain rigidity. So i am currently developing parts for another model with 30 x 30 extrusion, It would also be relatively easy to upsize to even bigger extusions as 3d printers evolve. I am still not sure what the maximum dimensions for a 20 x 20 build are, do you have any idea?

title: Hack filament sponge cleaner
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: I needed a sponge filament cleaner, my printer nozzles kept jamming. So before i printed one i just used 1/4 of an old kitchen sponge and a 1" wide binder clip. This works! It slides along the filament until it hits the feed tube and then the filament slides through it. The clamping force can be adjusted by how deep the binder clip grabs the sponge. The .stl file is just a place holder (its the bottom clamp to a handle bar mounting bracket I'm working on).

The session mount.
Not tested

Lathe Spindle Adapter

This customizable OpenSCAD model allows users to either 3D print a model of a spindle adapter that holds a nut, or cut sections of material and glue them together utilizing CNC/laser cutter. I have intended for the project to be cut into multiple sections and lined up. Construction pictures to follow. Export a module to STL then use DXF Extrusion to create files to be cut using projection.

projection(cut=false) import("/PATH/TO/STL/file.stl");

v3 - animation added to fulladapter module

v2 -

  1. Extended the diameter around the nut to include the through bolts. This prevents the wood or material from shearing on the lathe.
  2. Removed the module with nutsurround.
  3. Fixed full adapter preview.

v1 - I don't suggest using this as there needs to be more surface area around the nut, as well as adding support for bolts to add strength.

Variable Explanations:

spindle=diameter of the spindle

chuck=diameter of the adapter

nutsurround=amount of material surrounding the nut
nutsize=distance of the longest point to point outside of nut (pic below)
nutthick=thickness of the nut

materialthick=thickness of material to be cut into

centerbolt=diameter of center hole

mountholenum=number of mounting holes
mountholedia=mounting hole diameter

res=resolution of circles
How to Measure the Nut

I have designed my second version of the follow focus just like the pictures,but I wil publish it on the other "thing",after I finished my total tutorial,i will stick the link to this theme。(this design I knowed that it is a little difficult for makers to make one because it needs some customed made part like the worm gear ,that most of you i think you don't want to buy)

This version of shoulder rig had solved some problem in the first version,if you are interest in this design ,you can also check my previous design on this link:http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1571731

And the screws is still not been sorted out yet,I will finished it soon and upgrade this theme later.

And the worm gear link:https://item.taobao.com/item.htm?spm=a1z09.2.0.0.NGtbdA&id=17352109451&_u=765kgh64ed9
I really don't whether you guys can open it and buy it.....

and the rod that worm gear needs is 4mm&6mm
(if you buy it maybe you need to buy too )
and you can get it too from the same place,and the links is:https://item.taobao.com/item.htm?spm=a1z09.2.0.0.NGtbdA&id=45114001387&_u=765kgh6babe

the gears is all the same with the first version...

by the way, my brandnew twitter:https://twitter.com/Swanglei_DF

Printer:

DreamMaker

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

40%

Notes:

Important things:

These parts should be printed twice:
Handle_rig_down.stl
ScrewNorb.stl

These should be printed twice but the second one is mirrored:
Handle.stl
Handle_Beam.stl

most of the parts is printed for 20% infill and some parts that should be stronger I printed them for 40% infill.

Screws that needs:
M3_8mm 4pics
M3_25mm 2pics
M4_16nn 4pics
M4_20mm 1pics
M6_50mm 1pics
M6_20mm 6pics
M6 nuts 3pics

30mm_37mm_4mm bearing 2pics
15mm carbon fiber tubes (total : 1M~2M)

description.text:
Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:48133

Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=48133

Using the following options:

handleLength = 80
handleDiameter = 50
headType = 0
units = 25.4
text = D068 CROFT
myFont = write/Letters.dxf
headWidth = 90
headHeight = 35
textRotation = 0

Super simple spacer/damper for PrintrBot Simple Metal. The idea is to print 2 of these and place them under your PB Simple to help reduce the noise from vibration by reduction of contact area. Since PB Simple is fully metal, it transfers sound easily but this gives less contact area between the base of the printer and the object it is on. This has been tested on PLA first. I have not printed it on TPU yet, I figure TPU would be a better material due to its rubbery like material.

Test print was successful at .25 layer height with 15% infill in PLA but I have not tested it in TPU yet. Please let me know if this has made any difference or not.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/b6W5FVS1Tyn
